Hi Drew, sorry for the delay in this answer.  After 7 years going back an=
d trying to understand the old code for setting up these configurations is =
a challenge.  I believe what is going on is that we divide the left side of=
 the board into a 3 column and 4 row grid (giving 12 cells).  The same is d=
one for the right side of the board (so 12 cells there).  For the 144 combi=
nations, we step through all the 12 possible positions on the left side and=
 place a good there for the outer loop, and all the 12 possible positions o=
n the right side and place a food there on the inner loop.  Recall that eac=
h configuration involves only the placement of two pieces of food (one on t=
he left side and one on the right), and all the other food are in their usu=
al static positions at the start.  Then we get to 288 by flipping the start=
ing positions of the robots themselves and doing all the 144 configurations=
 again.

The one thing I'm a little uncertain about is if it was really 3 b=
y 4, or perhaps 4 by 3 on each side.  Or even 6 by 2, or maybe 2 by 6.  I'm=
 but I don't think it really matters for the purposes of this test since th=
e point is just to try a lot of different starting scenarios so the exact c=
olumns and rows shouldn't be critical.

I hope this helps,

ken

--- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, "ze_dakster" <drew.kirkpatrick@...> wrote:
>
> Ken,
> 
>=
 I'm wondering if you had any detail on the food placements you used for yo=
ur dominance tournament in the original competitive coevolution robot duel?=
 I'm looking over the paper "The Dominance Tournament Method of Monitoring =
Progress in Coevolution", and it gives a little more detail on the approach=
 taken. I'm still fuzzy on how you arrange the food items to get 144 positi=
ons per starting side, for 288 total evaluations. 
> 
> I suppose it's not =
critical for my purposes to *exactly* recreate the layouts as long as the d=
ominance tournament works, but if you have any documentation detailing the =
exact locations I might as well throw them in there for good measure. 
> 
>=
 
> -Drew Kirkpatrick
>
